column4: I repeat, just in case. I am running server 10.10, headless and without a WM, and wanted to migrate my system from one internal hd to another via ssh. both hds are in the system now. how would i do that?
clone the relevant partitions with partimage, reinstall grub (or just modify the configuration if the original disk will remain in place).
oh, and make sure that /etc/fstab entries reflect the new disk partitions.
actually, belay that last, the uuids will still be consistent.
clone with what cli util?
partimage.
that will clone the entire drive or indiv partitions?
use it to clone each partition.
and then edit grub?
as is said, yes.
one of my paritions (well, the non boot one really) is LVM. what should i resize it with to fit the new drive
in that case, take an LVM snapshot and relocate it to the new drive.
hm, i should probably say my whole story. i got a new HD and wanted to move the entire system to it so that i can later replace the original drive
so if there is a better way than cloning and resizing..
since you're using LVM anyway, why not simply extend the volume group to make use of the new drive? is the original drive no longer reliable?

sorry, i keep running around cuz i am at work. the reason i want to move my system (currently on a 0.5tb drive) to a new one (2tb) is because i intend to replace my 0.5tb drive with a bigger one eventually
therefore my mentality was that i probably should migrate the boot sector and whatever else not managed by lvm to the drive that should not get moved for a while
was there some part of my previous explanation that was unclear?
you have asked why i didn't decide to just extend lvm to the new drive
look, do what you like, i merely suggested it as an easier alternative.
Hah, I am not trying to defend my self. I am new to server management and wanted to know what's best to do in my case. Which, even with all i said, is partimage?

if you want to relocate to the new disk, partimage is an easy way to do so for the non-lvm partition. for the lvm volume group, (which i assume is all user data, home directories &cet?), you could just create another LVM group on the other disk, and copy the data directly. or you can make an LVM snapshot and move that over.
would you suggest copying the lvm partition and expanding it or extending it given my future plans
makes no difference. i would just extend it, unless you desperately need the extra space and only have room for two drives. in any event, i need to be going home, so i'll wish you luck and be off.
